{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2012}} [[File:Cooper, Oliver Cromwell.jpg|thumb|An unfinished [[portrait miniature]] of [[Oliver Cromwell]] by [[Samuel Cooper]].]] An '''unfinished creative work''' is a painting, [[novel]], musical composition, or other [[creative work]], that has not been brought to a completed state. Its creator may have chosen not to finish it, or may have been prevented from doing so by circumstances outside of their control, such as [[death]]. Such pieces are often the subject of speculation as to what the finished piece would have been like had the original creator completed the work. Sometimes artworks are finished by others and [[List of works published posthumously|released posthumously]]. Unfinished works have had profound influences on their genres and have inspired others in their own projects. The term can also refer to ongoing work which could eventually be finished (i.e. the creator is still living) and is distinguishable from "incomplete work", which can be a work that was finished but is no longer in its complete form.
There are many reasons for work not being completed. Works are usually stopped when their creator dies, although some, aware of their failing health, make sure that they set up the project for completion. If the work involves other people, such as a cast of actors or the subject of a portrait, it may be halted because of their unavailability. Projects that are too grandiose might never have been finished, while others should be feasible but their creator's continual unhappiness with them leads to abandonment.
Unfinished works by popular authors and artists may still be made public, sometimes in the state they were in when work was halted. Alternatively, another artist may finish the piece. In some fields work may appear unfinished but are actually finished, such as [[Donatello]]'s "[[non finito]]" technique in [[sculpture]].
==Media==
===Literature=== [[File:Kafka1906.jpg|thumb|[[Franz Kafka]]'s unfinished writings were released after his death despite his wishes for them to be destroyed.]] Many acclaimed [[author]]s have left work incomplete. Some such pieces have been published posthumously, either in their incomplete state or after being finished by somebody else.
It is the job of [[literary executor]]s to take charge of the work of a writer after their death. They must often decide what to do with incomplete work, using their own judgement if not given explicit instructions. In some cases this can lead to something happening to the work that was not originally intended, such as the release of [[Franz Kafka]]'s unfinished writings by [[Max Brod]] when Kafka had wished for them to be destroyed. These works have become iconic in [[Western literature]].<ref>{{es icon}} Contijoch, Francesc Miralles (2000) "Franz Kafka". ''Oceano Grupo Editorial, S.A. Barcelona.'' {{ISBN|84-494-1811-9}}.</ref> The posthumous publication of some of [[Ernest Hemingway]]'s unfinished novels was met with controversy. Several books were published, but it has been suggested that it is not within the jurisdiction of Hemingway's relatives or publishers to determine whether these works should be made available to the public. For example, scholars often disapprovingly note that the version of ''The Garden of Eden'' published by [[Charles Scribner's Sons]] in 1986, though not a revision of Hemingway's original words, nonetheless omits two-thirds of the original manuscript.<ref>[http://www.bookrags.com/shortguide-garden_of_eden/ BookRags] makes this quantitative note; it also reveals some more information about the publication of ''The Garden of Eden'' and offers some discussion of thematic content.</ref>
[[File:Twain1909.jpg|thumb|left|[[Mark Twain]] took 20 years to write three versions of ''[[The Mysterious Stranger]]'' but he did not finish any of them.]] Novels can remain unfinished because the author continually rewrites the story. When enough material exists, someone else can compile and combine the work, creating a finished story from several different drafts. [[Mark Twain]]'s ''[[The Mysterious Stranger]]'' was written in three different versions over a period of 20 years, none of which were completed. Twain biographer and literary executor [[Albert Paine]] combined the stories and published his version six years after Twain's death.<ref>"[https://web.archive.org/web/20040918015059/http://www.geocities.com/hal9000report/hal96.html A History of War]". Accessed 6 August 2006</ref> Similarly, [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] continuously rewrote ''[[The Silmarillion]]'' throughout his lifetime; a definitive version was still uncompiled at the time of his death, with some sections very fragmented. His son, [[Christopher Tolkien]], invited fantasy fiction writer [[Guy Gavriel Kay]] to reconstruct some parts of the book, and they eventually published a final version in 1977.<ref>Tolkienlibrary.com. "[http://www.tolkienlibrary.com/reviews/silmarillion.htm Collecting The Silmarillion]". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref> In 1980, Christopher Tolkien published another posthumous collection of his father's unfinished work, appropriately entitled ''[[Unfinished Tales]]''. Between 1982 and 1996, he published twelve volumes of ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]'', a substantial portion of which is unfinished and incomplete drafts. In 2007, Christopher Tolkien published another novel from his father entitled ''[[The Children of Húrin]]''. Like ''The Silmarillion'', Christopher assembled the novel from various incomplete drafts.
The size of a project can be such that a piece of literature is never finished. [[Geoffrey Chaucer]] never completed ''[[The Canterbury Tales]]'' to the extensive length that he originally intended. Chaucer had, however, already written much of the work at the time of his death, and the ''Canterbury Tales'' are considered to be a seminal work despite the unfinished status.<ref>6 December 2000. "[http://ccsun7.sogang.ac.kr/~anthony/Chaucer/index.htm The Canterbury Tales Geoffrey Chaucer : an overall survey] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060825163916/http://ccsun7.sogang.ac.kr/~anthony/Chaucer/index.htm |date=25 August 2006 }}". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref> English poet [[Edmund Spenser]] originally intended ''[[The Faerie Queene]]'' to consist of 12 books; even at its unfinished state—six books were published before Spenser's death—it is the longest epic poem in the English language.<ref>''The Faerie Queene'' is about [https://books.google.com/books?vid=LCCN13011576&id=dBqqd47DWK8C&q=%22faerie+queene%22+number+of+verses&dq=%22faerie+queene%22+number+of+verses&pgis=1 35,000 verses] long. By comparison, ''[[Savitri (book)|Savitri]]'' is about 24,000 verses long, and ''[[Beowulf]]'' is about 3,000 verses long. The Sanskrit language ''[[Mahabharata]]'', however, is many times longer than ''The Faerie Queene''.</ref> [[Honoré de Balzac]], the French novelist, completed nearly 100 pieces for his [[novel sequence]] ''[[La Comédie humaine]]'', but a planned 48 more were never finished.<ref>Pierre Citron edition, vol 1, 49-50.</ref> Notes and plot outlines left behind by an author may allow a successor to complete a novel or series of novels. [[Frank Herbert]] left behind extensive notes related to his [[Dune (franchise)|''Dune'' universe]], which led to son [[Brian Herbert]] and science fiction author [[Kevin J. Anderson]]'s completing several [[prequel]]s to the popular series.<ref>Dune 7 Blog. 16 December 2005. "[http://www.dunenovels.com/dune7blog/page21.html Conspiracy Theories] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071012125808/http://dunenovels.com/dune7blog/page21.html |date=12 October 2007 }}". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref> [[Mervyn Peake]], author of the [[Gormenghast series|Gormenghast]] novels, meant to write a complete biography of the main character, Titus, but died after only completing three books in the series.
Some works are presented as separate sections, each written at different times. This can lead to a piece appearing complete while the author actually intended for it to continue, or where other authors try to fake their own writing as part of the work. The first four [[canto]]s of [[George Gordon Byron, 6th Baron Byron|Lord Byron]]'s [[narrative poetry|narrative poem]] ''[[Don Juan (Byron)|Don Juan]]'' were written in 1818 and 1819, with a further 12 completed and published before his death in 1824. Numerous "continuations" of the story had been published by various publishing houses even between issues of the story, along with several fake conclusions. Byron had intended to continue the story, as evidenced by the find of the 17th canto after his death, but it is not clear how long the poem would continue or how it would conclude. It is still regarded as one of his greatest achievements.<ref>Hubeart, Thomas 1996. "[http://members.aol.com/basfawlty/byron.htm Whatever Happened to Don Juan? Finding the Ending to Byron's Poem]". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref> [[Charles Dickens]] was writing ''[[The Mystery of Edwin Drood]]'' in monthly installments when he died, completing just six of the twelve intended. The story surrounded the murder of the titular Edwin Drood; because the story was never finished, the murderer was never revealed.<ref>Perdue, David. David Perdue's Charles Dickens page. "[http://charlesdickenspage.com/drood.html The Mystery of Edwin Drood]". Accessed 10 August 2006.</ref> The book was still made into a film and [[The Mystery of Edwin Drood (musical)|a musical]], with the latter having the unusual concept of the audience voting for who they think is the murderer.<ref>Tams-Witmark Music Library. "[http://www.tamswitmark.com/musicals/drood.html Drood (The Mystery of Edwin Drood)]". Accessed 10 August 2006.</ref>
Other famous unfinished works of literature include: ''[[Hero and Leander (poem)|Hero and Leander]]'' by [[Christopher Marlowe]] (a completion was provided by [[George Chapman]]); the second part of ''[[Dead Souls]]'' by [[Gogol]]; ''[[Bouvard et Pécuchet]]'' by [[Gustave Flaubert]]; ''[[Weir of Hermiston]]'' by [[Robert Louis Stevenson]]; ''[[The Good Soldier Švejk]]'' by [[Jaroslav Hašek]]; ''[[Suite française (Irène Némirovsky)|Suite française]]'' by [[Irène Némirovsky]], ''[[Answered Prayers: The Unfinished Novel|Answered Prayers]]'' by [[Truman Capote]], ''[[The Last Tycoon]]'' by [[F. Scott Fitzgerald]], ''[[Uncertain Times]]'' by [[Richard Yates (novelist)|Richard Yates]], ''[[Sanditon]]'' by [[Jane Austen]], ''[[Mount Analogue]]'' by [[René Daumal]], ''[[The Pale King]]'' by [[David Foster Wallace]] and ''[[The Final Unfinished Voyage of Jack Aubrey]]''.
====Science, theology and philosophy==== [[File:SummaTheologiae.jpg|thumb|[[Thomas Aquinas|St. Thomas Aquinas]] stopped work on his ''[[Summa Theologica|Summa Theologiae]]'' in 1273 after a mystical experience.]] Religious works have also been left incomplete, leading to debates about the possible missing content. Some theologians consider the [[Gospel of Mark]], in its existing form, incomplete; the text after 16:8 is probably not original, thus creating speculation whether the author was arrested or died suddenly, or whether the end of the gospel could have broken away from the rest of the gospel as it was handed to the next person.<ref name="Mark's Incomplete Gospel">{{cite web|title=Christian Scriptures (New Testament) Alleged forgery in the Gospel of Mark|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/mark_16.htm|work=Religious Tolerance|publisher=Ontario Consultants on Religious Tolerance|accessdate=23 April 2012}}</ref> The Sunni Islamic classic Qur'anic commentary, Mafatihu-l-Ghayb, better known as Tafseer Al-Kabeer ([[Tafsir al-Kabir (al-Razi)]]) by [[Fakhr al-Din al-Razi]] was left unfinished and it was finished by either Qadi Shahab-ud-deen bin Khaleel al-Khauli, of [[Damascus]] (died 639 AH) or Shaikh Najm-ud-deen Ahmad bin Al-Qamooli (died 777 AH) as mentioned in Kashf-az-Zunoon. The [[Masnavi]], the most famous poem in [[Sunni]] Islamic [[Sufi poetry]] by [[Rumi]] was left unfinished and it was later finished by [[Mufti]] [[Ilahi Baksh Kandhlawi]] about five hundred years after the demise of [[Rumi]]. The [[Persian Bayán]], a [[religious text|scripture]] from [[Bábism]], was left unfinished when the [[Báb]] died. There have been some claims that the text has been completed by other people, though the Báb stated that it would be finished by [him] whom God shall make manifest.<ref>Poirier, Brent; Terry, Peter; Buck, Christopher; Momen, Moojan; Winters, Jonah. "[http://bahai-library.com/resources/tablets-notes/bayan/notes.html The Bayán]". Accessed 11 August 2006.</ref><ref>Pottenger, Elizabeth. "[http://bahai-library.com/pottenger_disclosure_station Baha'u'llah's Disclosure of His Station]". Accessed 11 August 2006.</ref> [[Thomas Aquinas|St. Thomas Aquinas]] abandoned his great work the ''[[Summa Theologica]]'' in 1273, citing a mystical experience during Mass. Its arguments for the existence of God continue to exert influence in philosophy and [[Christian theology]] more than 700 years later.<ref>Richards, Stephen. "[http://www.faithnet.org.uk/Theology/aquinas.htm Thomas Aquinas (1225-1274 CE)]". Accessed 20 August 2006.</ref> In Greek philosophy, [[Plato]]'s ''[[Critias (dialogue)|Critias]]'' was unfinished when Plato died at age 80.
The most influential document in [[computer science]] was [[John von Neumann]]'s ''[[First Draft of a Report on the EDVAC]]'', a 101-page manuscript dating from 1946. Littered with ellipses and spaces for the eventual addition of further material, von Neumann never completed it, as by that time its distribution had already influenced an explosion in postwar computer development. Its elaboration of the [[stored program]] concept and formalization of the logical design of computer architecture—ideas not all of which were original to von Neumann but which he first expressed in the mathematical language he favoured—endure in the architectures of modern computer systems.<ref>[[Herman Goldstine|Goldstine, Herman H]]. 1972. ''The Computer: from Pascal to von Neumann''. Princeton, New Jersey: Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|0-691-02367-0}}.</ref>
Still in computer science, the seminal work on algorithms, ''[[The Art of Computer Programming]]'' by [[Donald Knuth]], has had only the first three of its seven planned volumes written.
The first genuine [[historiography|historiographical]] work, the ''[[History of the Peloponnesian War]]'' by [[Thucydides]], was undergoing a major revision by the author at the time of his death, so different sections of it reflect a starkly contrasting general outlook on Persian influence in the events depicted.
===Drawings, paintings and sculptures===
[[File:Leonardo da Vinci - Adorazione dei Magi - Google Art Project.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Adoration of the Magi (Leonardo)|Adoration of the Magi]]'', an unfinished painting by [[Leonardo da Vinci]].]]
[[File:Treaty of Paris by Benjamin West 1783.jpg|thumb|right|[[Benjamin West]]'s painting of the delegates to the [[Treaty of Paris (1783)|Treaty of Paris]] which ended the [[American Revolutionary War]]. Out of shame for their country's defeat, the British delegates refused to pose and so the portrait was never finished.]] [[File:Dickens dream.jpg|thumb|right|''Dickens' Dream'', by [[Robert William Buss]], begun on the death of [[Charles Dickens]] in 1870, and incomplete at the time of the painter's death in 1875.]]
Artists leave behind incomplete work for a variety of reasons. A piece may not be completed if the subject becomes unavailable, such as in the changing of a landscape or the death of a person being painted. [[Elizabeth Shoumatoff]]'s ''[[Unfinished portrait of Franklin D. Roosevelt|Unfinished Portrait]]'' of 32nd [[President of the United States|U.S. president]] [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]] was started around noon on 12 April 1945 but left unfinished when Roosevelt died later that day. In other instances, outside circumstances can prevent the execution of an otherwise "finished" artwork: [[Leonardo da Vinci]] developed sketches and models for the {{convert|24|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} "Gran Cavallo" horse statue but the bronze to cast the sculpture was diverted to make cannons.<ref name="vezzosi">[[Alessandro Vezzosi|Vezzosi, Alessandro]], ''Leonardo da Vinci: Renaissance Man'', '[[New Horizons (Thames & Hudson)|New Horizons]]' series. London: Thames & Hudson, 1997, {{p.|73}}.</ref> Five hundred years later, two full-size sculptures were completed based on Leonardo's work.<ref name="leo-horse">''[http://www.leonardoshorse.org/never_was_is.asp The horse that never was...is!] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060903015833/http://www.leonardoshorse.org/never_was_is.asp |date=3 September 2006 }}'' Accessed 26 August 2006</ref> Technically his ''[[The Last Supper (Leonardo)|The Last Supper]]'' is unfinished. In most pictures it shows a roof, but at Milan, where the painting lies, it shows some [[Latin]] that is half done. [[Robert William Buss]] left unfinished his most famous painting, ''Dickens' Dream'', just as [[Charles Dickens]] himself had left a novel half-complete at his death.
Depending on the medium involved, it can be difficult for another artist to complete an unfinished artwork without damaging it. Some artists completed the paintings of their mentors, such as [[Giulio Romano]] is believed to have done on [[Raphael]]'s ''[[Transfiguration (Raphael)|Transfiguration]]'',<ref>Gerten-Jackson, Carol. "[http://cgfa.floridaimaging.com/raphael/raphael_bio.htm Raphael]". Accessed 10 August 2006.</ref> and [[Titian]] on [[Giorgione]]'s ''[[Sleeping Venus (Giorgione)|Sleeping Venus]]''.<ref>''[[The Economist]]''. 27 July 2006. "[http://www.economist.com/books/displaystory.cfm?story_id=7218457 Venetian art: The line of beauty]". Accessed 10 August 2006.</ref>
Instead of completing another artist's masterpiece, particularly when many years have passed, unfinished works frequently inspire others to create their own version. [[Michelangelo]] left several unfinished [[sculpture]]s and [[painting]]s, with sketches and partially completed paintings inspiring others.<ref>Lane, Jim. 24 March 1999. "[http://www.humanitiesweb.org/human.php?s=r&p=a&a=i&ID=452 A Painter's Legacy]". Accessed 6 August 2006.</ref> If the work is to be done on commission but is not finished it is commonly passed on to another artist. Leonardo da Vinci's work on the ''[[Adoration of the Magi (Leonardo)|Adoration of the Magi]]'' for the monastery of San Donato was halted when he left [[Florence]] for [[Milan]]. Still requiring an [[altarpiece]], the monks employed [[Filippino Lippi]] to create one.<ref>Universal Leonardo: ''[http://www.universalleonardo.org/lifeevent.php?event=242 Birth of Filippino Lippi]''. Retrieved 26 August 2006</ref> Both paintings now hang in the [[Uffizi]] gallery.<ref>Loadstar's Lair. "[http://www.lairweb.org.nz/leonardo/magi.html Adoration of the Magi]". Accessed 10 August 2006.</ref>
Paintings are usually sketched on the [[canvas]] before work begins, and sculptures are frequently planned using a [[maquette]]. These works-in-progress can be as sought after as (or even more sought after than) completed works by highly regarded artists because they help reveal the process of creating a work of art. [[Gian Lorenzo Bernini]], a sculptor from the [[Baroque]] period, made his bozzetti (an Italian term for the prototype sculpture) from [[wax]] or baked [[terracotta]] to show those that had commissioned him how the final piece was intended to look. Eleven of these bozzetti were displayed in an exhibition at the [[Art Institute of Chicago]] in 2004.<ref>Cassidy, Victor M. [[artnet]]. 2004. "[http://www.artnet.com/magazine_pre2000/reviews/cassidy/cassidy8-25-98.asp Chicago Report]". Accessed 22 August 2006.</ref> Some [[museum]]s specialise in collections of maquettes, such as the [[Museo dei Bozzetti]] in [[Pietrasanta]], [[Italy]].
During the [[Renaissance]], [[Donatello]] made sculptures that appeared unfinished by only sculpting part of the block, leaving the figure appearing to be stuck within the material. He called this technique "[[non finito]]", and it has been used by several artists since then.<ref>The Open Door Web Site. "[http://www.saburchill.com/history/events/014.html The Renaissance]". Accessed 10 August 2006.</ref>
In the age of [[mass media]], incomplete work can reach an audience due to sheer demand for material by the artist. ''[[Tintin and Alph-Art]]'', the 24th [[comics|comic]] in [[Hergé]]'s popular ''[[The Adventures of Tintin]]'' series, was unfinished at his death. Though he had illustrated much of the book, several sketched panels remained in the final scenes. The book was still published and the story can be followed despite the incomplete artwork.
===Architecture, construction and engineering=== {{See also|Unfinished building}}
Many [[construction]] or [[engineering]] projects have remained unfinished at various stages of development. The work may be finished as a [[blueprint]] or [[whiteprint]] and never be realised, or be abandoned during construction.
There are numerous [[unfinished building]]s that remain partially constructed in countries around the world, some of which can be used in their incomplete state, while others remain as mere shells. An example of the latter is the [[Ryugyong Hotel]] in [[North Korea]]. If finished, it would become the tallest hotel in the world and the seventh [[List of largest buildings in the world|largest building]]<ref>[[Emporis]]. "[http://www.emporis.com/en/wm/bu/?id=130967 Ryugyong Hotel]". Accessed 20 August 2006.</ref> but is uninhabitable and will not be completed due to the cost and the poor structural integrity.<ref>Emporis. 28 July 2000. "[http://www.emporis.com/en/bu/nc/ne/?id=100302 Ryugyong Hotel on hold] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061021204752/http://www.emporis.com/en/bu/nc/ne/?id=100302 |date=21 October 2006 }}". Accessed 20 August 2006.</ref> Some projects are intentionally left with an unfinished appearance, particularly the [[folly|follies]] of the late 16th to 18th century.
There are many reasons for construction works being halted. Amongst others, they include a changing financial climate, unforeseen structural weaknesses, and a dramatic shift in the politics of a country. Work on the [[Palace of Soviets]], a project to construct the world's largest building in [[Moscow]], was halted when the city [[Operation Barbarossa|was attacked]] during [[World War II]].<ref>Beautiful Atrocities. 8 April 2005. "[http://beautifulatrocities.com/archives/2005/04/stalins_vision.html Stalin's Vision of Moscow] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060629054426/http://beautifulatrocities.com/archives/2005/04/stalins_vision.html |date=29 June 2006 }}". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref>
Some buildings are in a cycle of near-perpetual construction, with work lasting for decades or even centuries. [[Antoni Gaudí]]'s [[Sagrada Família]] in [[Barcelona]] has been under construction for around 120 years, having started in [[1882]]. Work was delayed by the [[Spanish Civil War]], during which part of the original models were destroyed. After the restoration of these models, the works are still in progress and the prevision is that the building will be finished in 2026. Today, even with portions of the [[basilica]] incomplete, it is still the most popular tourist destination in Barcelona with 1.5 million visitors every year. Gaudí spent 40 years of his life overseeing the project and is buried in the crypt.<ref>Barcelona Information. "[http://www.barcelona-information.com/sagrada-familia.html Barcelona Sagrada Familia] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060823045014/http://www.barcelona-information.com/sagrada-familia.html |date=23 August 2006 }}". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref> Also in Barcelona, construction on the [[Barcelona Cathedral]] started in 1298, but its dome and central tower only was finished in 1913, 615 years later. [[Germany]]'s [[Cologne Cathedral]] took even longer to complete, from 1248 to 1880, a total of 632 years.<ref>[[UNESCO]] World Heritage. "[http://whc.unesco.org/pg.cfm?cid=31&id_site=292 Cologne Cathedral]". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref>
[[File:Kolner Dom kurz vor der Fertigstellung 1880.jpg|thumb|left|Construction of [[Cologne Cathedral]] took over 600 years.]] It is not only buildings that have failed during the construction phase. In the 1920s, the [[White Star Line]] hired the shipbuilders [[Harland and Wolff]] to build the first {{convert|1000|ft|m|adj=mid|-long}} [[ocean liner]], with the planned name of ''[[Oceanic (unfinished ship)|Oceanic]]''. However, a dispute between the companies and eventually the [[Great Depression]] halted the construction, and eventually the portion of the [[keel]] already constructed was broken up and used in building the smaller but similar ship, the ''[[MV Britannic]]''.<ref>Othfors, Daniel. "[http://www.greatoceanliners.net/intendedgiants.html Intended Giants of the Seas]". Accessed 20 August 2006.</ref> In the 1970s the [[Hoan Bridge]] in [[Milwaukee, Wisconsin|Milwaukee]], [[Wisconsin]] was out of use for five years after its construction when the connecting roads were not completed. In the 1980s, during the [[Iran–Iraq War]], [[Iraq]]i president [[Saddam Hussein]] commissioned the [[Project Babylon|Babylon project]]. The [[supergun]] design by [[Gerald Bull]] was never fully constructed after Bull's [[assassination]] in March 1990.<ref>Wade, Mark. Encyclopedia Astronautica. "[http://www.astronautix.com/lvs/babongun.htm Babylon Gun] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101119144359/http://astronautix.com/lvs/babongun.htm |date=19 November 2010 }}". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref><ref>Sherman, Robert. Federation of American Scientists. 8 October 2000. "[http://www.fas.org/nuke/guide/iraq/other/supergun.htm Project Babylon Supergun / PC-2]". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref>
Many projects do not get to the construction phase and are halted during or after planning. [[Ludwig II of Bavaria]] commissioned several designs for [[Falkenstein Castle (Pfronten)|Castle Falkenstein]], with the fourth plan being vastly different from the first. The first two designs were turned down, one because of costs and one because the design displeased Ludwig, and the third designer withdrew from the project. The fourth and final plan was completed and some [[infrastructure]] was prepared for the site, but Ludwig died before construction work began.<ref>Yan, Mark. King Ludwig II of Bavaria - his Life and Art. "[https://web.archive.org/web/20070115143708/http://us.geocities.com/sharmar505/falkenst.htm Falkenstein]". Accessed 21 August 2006.</ref> The [[Palace of Whitehall]], at the time the largest [[palace]] in Europe, was mostly destroyed by a fire in 1698. Sir [[Christopher Wren]], most famous for his role in rebuilding several churches after the [[Great Fire of London]] in 1666, sketched a proposed replacement for a part of the palace, but financial constraints prevented construction.
[[File:WhitehallWren.jpg|thumb|Sir [[Christopher Wren]]'s 1698 sketch for a rebuilt [[Palace of Whitehall]].]] Computer technology has allowed for [[3D computer graphics|3D representations]] of projects to be shown before they are built. In some cases the construction is never started and the [[computer simulation|computer model]] is the nearest that anyone can ever get to seeing the finished piece. For example, in 1999 Kent Larson's exhibition "''Unbuilt Ruins: Digital Interpretations of Eight Projects by Louis I. Kahn''" showed computer images of designs completed by noted [[architect]] [[Louis Kahn]] but never built.<ref>Eiteljorg II, Harrison. 1999. CSA Newsletter, "[http://csanet.org/newsletter/spring99/nls9902.html Seeing Buildings that Were Never Built]". Accessed 21 August 2006.</ref> Computer simulations can also be used to create [[prototype]]s of engineering projects and test them before they are actually made; this has allowed the design process to be more successful and efficient.
Even without being constructed, many architectural designs and ideas have had a lasting influence. The [[Russia]]n [[constructivism (art)|constructivism movement]] started in 1913<ref>HuntFor.com. "[http://www.huntfor.com/arthistory/C20th/constructivism.htm Constructivism]". Accessed 25 August 2006.</ref> and was taught in the [[Bauhaus]] and other architecture schools, leading to numerous architects integrating it into their style.<ref>[[University of Westminster]]. "[http://www.westminsterjournalism.co.uk/coursesite/magazines/123const.html Constructivism] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071006232214/http://www.westminsterjournalism.co.uk/coursesite/magazines/123const.html |date=6 October 2007 }}". Accessed 25 August 2006.</ref><ref>GrahamPotter.com. "[http://www.grahampotter.com/constructivism.html Constructivism synopsis]". Accessed 25 August 2006.</ref>
===Music===
====Classical music==== {{see also|Unfinished symphony|Composer tributes (classical music)}} In the days of [[classical music]] all compositions were sketched on manuscripts – the technology to record music did not exist. Often these manuscripts are roughly sketched, with drafting work scribbled over the top of the music, and have been found in unordered piles. Many [[unfinished symphony|unfinished symphonies]] have been pieced together from these original manuscripts by other composers, after the original author's death, with some remaining incomplete until many decades later. One of the most famous examples of unfinished musical compositions is [[Franz Schubert]]'s ''[[Symphony No. 8 (Schubert)|Symphony No. 8 in B minor]]'', or as it is more commonly known, ''The Unfinished Symphony''.<ref>Vial Jaffe, Jane. Stockton Symphony Association. "[http://www.stocktonsymphony.org/Program06-Schubert.htm Symphony No. 8 in B minor, D759] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060822051700/http://www.stocktonsymphony.org/Program06-Schubert.htm |date=22 August 2006 }}". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref> Another famous unfinished classical piece is [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]]'s ''[[Requiem (Mozart)|Requiem]]'', famous in part because of the numerous myths and legends that surround its creation and in part because of Mozart's prestige. At the time of his death, Mozart had fully orchestrated only the first movement, leaving nine further movements in varying states of completion. [[Franz Xaver Süssmayr]], an acquaintance of Mozart, finished the nine incomplete movements and wrote four more. [[Gustav Mahler]]'s [[Symphony No. 10 (Mahler)|Symphony No. 10]] was incomplete, with only drafts, sketches, and two mostly orchestrated movements existing at the composer's death. Several people have "completed" it with varying degrees of success, the most notable of these being [[Deryck Cooke]]'s "performing version of the draft."<ref name = Cooke>{{cite book|title = A Performing Version for the Draft of the Tenth Symphony|last= Cooke|first= Deryck |publisher = Associated Music Publishers|year=1976|isbn = 0-571-51094-9}}</ref>
[[File:Bach-unfinishedfugue.jpg|thumb|300px|[[Johann Sebastian Bach|J. S. Bach]]'s ''[[The Art of Fugue]]'' breaks off abruptly during ''Contrapunctus XIV''.]] Some compositions are finished "in the style of" the original composer, with someone who is highly familiar with the work adopting the same writing style and continuing the musical tone. [[Johann Sebastian Bach]]'s ''[[The Art of Fugue]]'', which was broken off abruptly during ''Contrapunctus XIV'', probably shortly before the death of the composer, was first published in the mid 18th century. Many reconstructions have been written, but in 1991 [[Zoltán Göncz]] used the form of a [[Fugue#perm|permutation fugue]] to make a strong argument as to the structure of the Fugue to come.<ref>Göncz, Z. 1997. Reconstruction of the Final Contrapunctus of ''[[The Art of Fugue]], in: ''International Journal of Musicology'' Vol. 5, pp. 25–93. {{ISBN|3-631-49809-8}}; Vol. 6, pp. 103–119. 1998 {{ISBN|3-631-33413-3}}.</ref> (See external links.) Sir [[Edward Elgar]] was composing a [[Symphony No. 3 (Elgar/Payne)|Symphony No. 3]] at the time of his death and left 130 pages of sketches. These sketches were put into a reasonable order, orchestrated in the style of Elgar, and elaborated by [[Anthony Payne]]. Payne's reconstruction has been played numerous times to great acclaim.<ref>{{cite news| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/special_report/1998/elgar/56393.stm | work=BBC News | title=Anthony Payne on Elgar's Symphony No 3 | date=13 February 1998 | accessdate=26 May 2010}}</ref>
Some works, deemed complete by the composer, are nonetheless augmented for non-musical reasons. In May 2000 composer [[Colin Matthews]] premiered his "completion" of [[Gustav Holst]]'s ''[[The Planets]]'', whereby he composed a piece for the ninth planet [[Pluto]], giving it the name "Pluto, The Renewer". When Holst had written the original piece Pluto had not been discovered, and this addition therefore updated the suite and completed the eight [[movement (music)|movement]]s that represented the planets of the [[solar system]] (Earth was never included) some 80 years after it was originally performed.<ref>Andante. December 2002. "[http://www.andante.com/article/article.cfm?id=19430 Completing Holst's Cosmos] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061122065450/http://www.andante.com/article/article.cfm?id=19430 |date=22 November 2006 }}". Accessed 26 August 2006.</ref> In August 2006 Pluto was officially demoted to a [[dwarf planet]], meaning that Holst's original work now more accurately represents the solar system.<ref>[[BBC News]]. 24 August 2006. "[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/sci/tech/5282440.stm Pluto loses status as a planet]". Accessed 26 August 2006.</ref>
Some extremely famous 20th century [[opera]]s have been left incomplete at their composers' deaths. [[Giacomo Puccini]] left the finale of ''[[Turandot]]'' unfinished and the missing music had to be provided by [[Franco Alfano]] for the premiere in 1926. Recently, [[Luciano Berio]] composed an alternative ending. [[Alban Berg]] had only finished the first two acts of his opera ''[[Lulu (opera)|Lulu]]'' at the time of his death in 1935. Due to objections from his widow it was not until 1979 that a full version was performed, with music for the final act devised by [[Friedrich Cerha]] using Berg's sketches.<ref>''Viking Opera Guide'', ed. Holden (Viking, 1994): articles on Puccini and Berg.</ref>
Other musical works which are unfinished but performable, are simply given in their incomplete state. Schubert's symphony is the most famous, but [[Anton Bruckner]]'s [[Symphony No. 9 (Bruckner)|Ninth Symphony]] is performed without a finale, and in [[Karl Amadeus Hartmann]]'s ''[[Gesangsszene]]'', the final words of [[Jean Giraudoux]]'s text, left unset at the composer's death, are simply spoken by the soloist.
Some other well-known examples of unfinished works completed by other hands include: * [[Béla Bartók]]'s [[Viola Concerto (Bartók)|Viola Concerto]], completed by [[Tibor Serly]] and others * [[Ludwig van Beethoven]]'s [[Symphony No. 10 (Beethoven/Cooper)|Symphony No. 10]], completed by [[Barry Cooper (musicologist)|Barry Cooper]] * [[Alexander Borodin]]'s opera ''[[Prince Igor]]'', completed by [[Nikolai Rimsky-Korsakov]] and [[Alexander Glazunov]] * [[Ernest Chausson]]'s [[String Quartet (Chausson)|String Quartet]], completed by [[Vincent d'Indy]] * [[Claude Debussy]]'s opera ''[[Rodrigue et Chimène]]'', completed by [[Edison Denisov]] * [[Gaetano Donizetti]]'s opera ''[[Le duc d'Albe]]'', completed by [[Matteo Salvi]] * [[Manuel de Falla]]'s opera ''[[Atlántida (opera)|Atlántida]]'', completed by [[Ernesto Halffter]] * [[Fromental Halévy]]'s opera ''[[Noé (opera)|Noé]]'', completed by [[Georges Bizet]] * [[Charles Ives]]' [[Universe Symphony (Ives)|Universe Symphony]], completed by various composers, including [[Larry Austin]] * [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]]'s [[Great Mass in C minor, K. 427|Great Mass in C minor]], completed in various versions, among which are those by [[Robert D. Levin]] and [[Benjamin-Gunnar Cohrs]] * [[Modest Mussorgsky]]'s opera ''[[The Fair at Sorochyntsi]]'', completed in various versions by [[César Cui]], [[Nikolai Tcherepnin]], [[Vissarion Shebalin]] and [[Emil Cooper]] * Mussorgsky's opera ''[[Khovanshchina]]'', completed in versions by Rimsky-Korsakov; [[Maurice Ravel]] and [[Igor Stravinsky]] working together; and [[Dmitri Shostakovich]] * Mussorgsky's opera ''[[Zhenitba]]'', completed in various versions, including Rimsky-Korsakov, [[Aleksandr Gauk]], [[Mikhail Ippolitov-Ivanov]], [[Alexander Tcherepnin]], [[Gennady Rozhdestvensky]] and [[Vyacheslav Nagovitsyn]] * [[Sergei Prokofiev]]'s opera ''[[Maddalena (opera)|Maddalena]]'', completed by [[Edward Downes]] * [[Giacomo Puccini]]'s opera ''[[La rondine]]'', completed by [[Lorenzo Ferrero]] * [[Ottorino Respighi]]'s opera ''[[Lucrezia (opera)|Lucrezia]]'', completed by [[Elsa Respighi]] * [[Arnold Schoenberg]]'s opera ''[[Moses und Aron]]'', third act written but never set to music * [[Franz Schubert]]'s [[Symphony No. 7 (Schubert)|Symphony No. 7]] and [[Symphony No. 10 (Schubert)|10]], completed by [[Brian Newbould]] * [[Alexander Scriabin]]'s [[Mysterium (Scriabin)|Mysterium]], of which the ''Prefatory Action'' was completed by [[Alexander Nemtin]] * [[Pyotr Ilyich Tchaikovsky]]'s [[Piano Concerto No. 3 (Tchaikovsky)|Piano Concerto No. 3 in E flat]], completed by [[Sergei Taneyev]] ** This work was originally intended to be a [[Symphony in E flat (Tchaikovsky)|Symphony in E flat]]; it would have been Tchaikovsky's 6th symphony had he not abandoned it (the work now known as his [[Symphony No. 6 (Tchaikovsky)|Symphony No. 6 in B minor, ''Pathétique'']] is a completely different work). Tchaikovsky converted his sketches into a piano concerto, and in that form it was completed by Taneyev. However, Semyon Bogatyrev took the original sketches and completed the symphony Tchaikovsky had first planned, publishing it as Tchaikovsky's "Symphony No. 7". * [[Carl Maria von Weber]]'s opera ''[[Die drei Pintos]]'', completed by [[Gustav Mahler]]
[[Peter Schickele]] parodied the concept in his "Unbegun Symphony," which contains only movements III and IV because, as Schickele put it, "I was born too late to write the first two movements."
====Modern recordings==== Since recording equipment has been an integral part of writing music it has been possible to use the original master tapes and [[demo (music)|demos]] to construct a song from the parts that had already been completed. Many demos are released officially if the artist has been unable (or unwilling) to complete it, or made available as a [[bootleg recording]]. The continued popularity of [[the Beatles]] led to "[[Free as a Bird]]" and "[[Real Love (John Lennon song)|Real Love]]" being released in the mid-1990s after the band members pieced together incomplete recordings by the deceased [[John Lennon]].<ref>Sullivan, Caroline. [[Guardian Unlimited]], 21 November 1995. "[https://www.theguardian.com/thebeatles/story/0,,606548,00.html Do they believe in yesterday?]". Accessed 6 August 2006.</ref> Both songs reached the top five in the British singles chart.
[[File:Brian Wilson.jpg|thumb|[[Brian Wilson]] performing ''[[Brian Wilson Presents Smile|Smile]]'' as a solo artist in 2005]]
[[The Beach Boys]]' ''[[Smile (The Beach Boys album)|Smile]]'' is considered the most legendary unreleased album in the history of popular music.{{sfn|Bogdanov|Woodstra|Erlewine|2002|p=72}}{{sfn|Jones|2008|p=63}} Recorded in 1966 and 1967, ''Smile'' was to be the followup to the album ''[[Pet Sounds]]'' (1966), but due to [[Brian Wilson]]'s deteriorating mental health and increased friction among the band members, the band abandoned the project after completing numerous recordings slated for the project. In 2004, Wilson and writing partner [[Van Dyke Parks]] went into the studio, and newly recorded the material and released it as a completed solo album.
Other famous unfinished rock albums include [[the Beatles]]' ''[[Let It Be#Get Back albums|Get Back]]'', [[the Who]]'s [[rock opera]] ''[[Lifehouse (rock opera)|Lifehouse]]'', [[Bob Dylan]]'s ''[[The Basement Tapes]]'', and [[Jimi Hendrix]]'s ''[[First Rays of the New Rising Sun]]''.<ref name=unt-unrel>{{Citation |last=Unterberger |first=Richie |date=2015-04-13 |title=The Top Ten Unreleased Albums From the Mid-1960s Through the Early 1970s |publisher= |url=http://www.richieunterberger.com/wordpress/the-top-ten-unreleased-albums-from-the-mid-1960s-through-the-early-1970s/ |accessdate=2017-10-02}}</ref> All have been released, in whole or part, in various posthumous forms in the ensuing years,<ref name=unt-unrel/> ''[[Lifehouse (rock opera)|Lifehouse]]'' being another case of using demos in order to present a completed work.
Several artists have found that some of their studio work have been leaked onto the [[Internet]] before their album has been completed. [[System of a Down]]'s 2002 follow-up to ''[[Toxicity (album)|Toxicity]]'', untitled at the time, was leaked onto the Internet as [[MP3]] files. When the album was released under the title ''[[Steal This Album!]]'' the songs were significantly different from the work-in-progress, with different titles, lyrics and even melodies. There were some reports that the changes were a direct result of negative feedback about the leaked material.<ref>Sputnikmusic. "[http://www.sputnikmusic.com/album.php?albumid=135 System of a Down - ''Steal This Album!'']". Accessed 12 August 2006.</ref>
Some artists will try to ensure that their work is completed (as much as possible) before their health prevents them from continuing. [[Johnny Cash]], aware of his failing health, made sure that he recorded the vocals for 60 more songs, with the music being completed after his death. These songs were compiled by producer [[Rick Rubin]] and released as ''[[American V: A Hundred Highways]]'' and ''[[American VI]]''.<ref>Gundersen, Edna. [[USA Today]], 1 May 2006. "[https://www.usatoday.com/life/music/reviews/2006-05-01-cash_x.htm Johnny Cash's final work yields 2 more albums]". Accessed 6 August 2006.</ref> However, not all artists get the chance to complete their work before their death, and the recordings that are made public may be somewhat different from what had originally been intended.{{original research inline|date=November 2016}} ''[[From a Basement on the Hill]]'' by [[Elliott Smith]] was released posthumously in 2004 with comments from the initial album producer saying that "[t]he record he would have delivered would [have] had more songs, would have had different mixes and [been] a little more in your face".<ref>Confabulators. "[http://www.confabulators.com/2005/elliott-smith-lives-again-from-a-basement-on-the-hill-v2 Elliott Smith Lives Again! From a Basement on the Hill V.2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060212172657/http://www.confabulators.com/2005/elliott-smith-lives-again-from-a-basement-on-the-hill-v2 |date=12 February 2006 }}". Accessed 24 August 2006.</ref>
[[Richard Carpenter (musician)|Richard Carpenter]] released several tracks decades after his sister Karen died in 1983, leaving a multitude of unfinished work. One track, released on the "Interpretations" album in the mid-nineties, included Karen's lead vocal for the song "[[Tryin' to Get the Feeling Again]]" which had previously been recorded and released by [[Barry Manilow]]. The lead had been lost for years on a mislabelled tape. Strings, piano, and backup singers were added to the sound of Karen's lead vocal, while Richard left the sound of her turning the lead sheet over in the finished product. Another track was Karen's cover "[[The Rainbow Connection]]", which had been written by [[Kenny Ascher]] and [[Paul Williams (songwriter)|Paul Williams]] for [[Jim Henson]] to sing as [[Kermit The Frog]] in ''[[The Muppet Movie]]'' (1979). Recording it only a year later, Richard claims that Karen just did not like the song and that was why it was omitted from their 1981 album, ''[[Made in America (Carpenters album)|Made In America]]''. A toy piano, choir, and strings were added against Karen's vocals. The song was released in 2001 on the album ''[[As Time Goes By (Carpenters album)|As Time Goes By]]''.{{citation needed|date=November 2016}}
===Film=== [[File:Orson Welles 1937.jpg|thumb|[[Orson Welles]] left behind numerous unfinished films.]] [[Film]]s may not be completed for several reasons, with some being shelved during different stages of the production. ''[[Arrive Alive]]'' was scrapped after a week of filming when the comedy was not living up to the screenplay. Shelving a film without it ever being released can be very expensive for the studios, with ''Arrive Alive'' costing $7 million.
With so many people involved in [[filmmaking]] it is very possible for a film to remain incomplete because of an injury or death. While a member of the crew (even a [[film producer|producer]] or [[film director|director]]) can often be replaced, it is much more difficult to change to a different [[actor]] if many of the scenes have already been filmed. For example, ''[[Dark Blood]]'' was cancelled halfway through filming due to the death of its star [[River Phoenix]]; however, the film premiered to a private guest audience on September 27, 2012 at the Netherlands Film Festival in Utrecht, Netherlands. Some films have been completed despite such problems. A famous example is [[Bruce Lee]]'s ''[[Game of Death]]''; Lee died during the filming and the rest of the filming was finished by [[Tai Chung Kim]], a Lee look-alike; and [[Yuen Biao]], a then-stunt actor who later became a TV/movie actor. His son, [[Brandon Lee]], also suffered from the same fate: he died after filming most of ''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'', but the remaining scenes were played by [[stunt double]] [[Chad Stahelski]] with Lee's face digitally composited onto the double.<ref>[[Urban Legends Reference Pages]]. 7 December 1997. "[http://www.snopes.com/movies/actors/brandlee.htm Brandon Lee]". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref>
Continued delays can prevent a film from ever being completed. ''[[Something's Got to Give]]'' was a [[1962 in film|1962 film]] with a difficult production history, which included the firing of leading lady [[Marilyn Monroe]]. She was later rehired but died before filming started; without the delay the film might have been completed.<ref>CoverUps.com. "[http://www.coverups.com/monroe/countdown.htm Marilyn Monroe's Death, Countdown To Tragedy] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060820043058/http://www.coverups.com/monroe/countdown.htm |date=20 August 2006 }}". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref>
In [[Orson Welles]]' lifetime his unfinished films became legendary. For decades he worked on a version of ''[[Don Quixote (unfinished film)|Don Quixote]]'', and he claimed that the film could be finished despite the deaths of his two leading actors.<ref>"The Orson Welles Story", ''Arena'', BBC TV 1982.</ref> ''[[Citizen Kane]]'' remains one of the only films that was released as Welles intended, with most of his other films remaining incomplete or being changed by the studios. His death on 10 October 1985 came while he was working on ''[[The Other Side of the Wind]]'' and ''[[The Dreamers (unfinished film)|The Dreamers]]'', the former being completed.<ref>Cabrelli, Paolo. 22 May 2006. "[http://www.stylusmagazine.com/articles/weekly_article/sunken-treasure-the-drowned-world-of-lost-movies.htm Sunken Treasure: The Drowned World of Lost Movies]". Retrieved 17 August 2009.</ref>
[[Animation|Animated films]], though less vulnerable to problems such as the death of an actor, can still fail to be completed. ''[[The Thief and the Cobbler]]'' was a twenty-six-year [[animation|animated film]] project by [[Richard Williams (animator)|Richard Williams]] which was taken away from him and completed by [[Fred Calvert]].<ref>Briney, Daniel. 21 August 2001. "[http://www.culturecartel.com/review.php?aid=1000025/ The Thief and the Cobbler: How the Best Was Lost, 1968-1995]" at CultureCartel. Accessed 12 November 2006.</ref> The [[workprint]] of the original film became available as a bootleg, and there have been several attempts to restore the film, most notably Garrett Gilchrist's "Recobbled" cut. The 1978 animated adaptation of ''[[The Lord of the Rings (1978 film)|The Lord of the Rings]]'' was not viewed by the studio as enough of a commercial success to warrant the funding of a sequel, thus not completing the story from the original trilogy of books.<ref>Cochran, Connor. March 2006. "[http://www.conlanpress.com/html/zaentz_b.html Peter S. Beagle and the Saul Zaentz Company] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120722165309/http://www.conlanpress.com/html/zaentz_b.html |date=22 July 2012 }}". Accessed 25 August 2006.</ref>
===Software=== Computer [[software]], particularly [[computer and video games|games]], are sometimes cancelled quite far into their [[software engineering|development]]. Occasionally they are demonstrated to the press so that [[Technical preview|preview]]s can be written but are never completed or published. ''[[Amen: The Awakening]]'' had an extensive preview written in the magazine ''PC Paradox'' in 1999, including numerous [[screenshot]]s, which generated a lot of interest in the project. However, it was cancelled the following year.<ref>PlanetPhillip. 18 August 2004. "[http://www.planetphillip.com/posts/amen-the-awakening/ Amen: The Awakening] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061016152052/http://www.planetphillip.com/posts/amen-the-awakening/ |date=16 October 2006 }}". Accessed 12 August 2006.</ref> Due to continued interest in a game, some are eventually made available in their unfinished state. ''[[Combat 2]]'', the sequel to the 1977 [[Atari 2600|Atari VCS]]-bundled game ''[[Combat (video game)|Combat]]'', was never completed, but many years later, at the 2001 [[Classic Gaming Expo]], 200 copies of the unfinished game were sold after a company created a box and manual.<ref>AtariAge. "[http://www.atariage.com/software_page.html?SoftwareLabelID=1137 Combat Two]". Accessed 12 August 2006.</ref>
Software undergoes a [[software testing|testing phase]] that helps to eliminate problems before it is released; however, [[development stage|beta testing]] is a form of testing where the software is open to the public (usually limited to a set number of people or organisations) but is still essentially unfinished. This is often an important part of the development of a software package.
If a piece of software is becoming overly delayed the developer may just release the program despite the presence of a few [[software bug|bugs]]. The Internet has allowed [[patch (computing)|patch]]es to be deployed that fix these bugs, but before such technology was available the problems could not be fixed after the game was published. Even with this, a game with too many bugs when it is made public will receive very poor reviews that will undoubtedly affect sales. For example, 2002's ''[[Destroyer Command]]'' received some very positive reviews about many aspects of the game but was criticised for the number of glitches it contained that, given a lengthier software testing phase, should have been fixed.<ref>Metacritic. "[http://www.metacritic.com/games/platforms/pc/destroyercommand Destroyer Command]". Accessed 12 August 2006.</ref> Some developers choose to disable certain features in order to release the game on time, especially if a project has seen an amount of [[feature creep]]. One such title was [[Cinemaware]]'s ''[[Defender of the Crown]]'', which was released before all the features were completed when the company was faced with a strict deadline and the loss of two programmers.<ref>Hall Of Light. "''[http://hol.abime.net/305 Defender Of The Crown]''". Accessed 20 August 2006.</ref>
==In law== Unfinished work is often covered by the [[copyright]] laws of the country of origin. The [[United States]] have taken the step of creating a law which specifically mentions ongoing work, whereby work which is in progress but will in the future be completed can be covered by copyright. On 27 April 2005 the "Artist's Rights and Theft Prevention Act", a subpart of the [[Family Entertainment and Copyright Act]], was signed into U.S. law. This act allows for organisations or individuals to apply for copyright protection on unfinished commercial products, such as [[software]], films, and other visual or audible media.<ref>[[Center for Democracy and Technology]]. April 2005. {{cite web|url= http://www.cdt.org/copyright/20050426s167analysis.pdf |title=Analysis of the Family Entertainment and Copyright Act of 2005 (S. 167) }} {{small|(74.1 KB)}} . Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref> For example, a [[photographer]] can preregister a photograph by giving a written description of what the final piece (or collection thereof) will look like before the work is finished.<ref>Lang, Daryl. 14 November 2005. "[http://www.pdnonline.com/pdn/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1001479563 New Copyright Law Lets Photographers Register Unfinished Work]". Accessed 9 August 2006.</ref>
In copyright law, an artistic creation that includes major, basic copyrighted aspects of an original, previously created first work is known as a '[[derivative work]]'. This holds for all kinds of work, including those that have never officially been published. The rights of the first work's originator must be granted to the secondary work for it to be rightfully called a 'derivative work'. If no copyright permission is granted from the originator, it is instead called a 'copy'. Upon completion of the new piece both parties hold a joint copyright status, with both having to agree to any publications. When the copyright has lapsed for the original work the second artist fully owns the copyright for their work, but cannot stop distribution of the original piece or another artist from completing the work in their own way. However, such copyrights can only be granted if the work shows significant new creative content.<ref name="publaw">{{cite web |last=Lloyd |first=L. Rich |publisher=The Publishing Law Center|year= 1998 |url=http://www.publaw.com/publicdomain.html |title=The Public Domain and the Impact of New Legislation |accessdate=26 August 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last=Wehrli |first=John E |date=14 October 2005 |url=http://www.lbl.gov/Workplace/patent/ch9.html|title=Computer Software and Copyright |accessdate=26 August 2006}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Lacuna (manuscripts)|Lacuna]] – a gap in a [[manuscript]], [[inscription]], text, or a musical work. *[[List of comics solicited but never published]] *[[Lost work]] *[[Shared universe]] – a [[literary technique]] whereby a series can continue after the death of the original author. *[[Tower of Babel]] – a tower mentioned in [[Book of Genesis|Genesis]] in the [[Bible]] where [[God]] halted the construction.
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
== External links == * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2sTsCtiUpn0 J. S. Bach: Contrapunctus XIV (reconstruction) – part 1] (YouTube Video) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1DPqVVfm9JU J. S. Bach: Contrapunctus XIV (reconstruction) – part 2] (YouTube Video) * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KdiHaWHJNc8 J. S. Bach: Completed Fugue in C minor BWV 562:2] (YouTube Video)
{{DEFAULTSORT:Unfinished Work}} [[Category:Unfinished creative works| ]]

The '''Valmadonna Trust Library''' was a collection of 13,000 printed books and manuscripts printed in [[Hebrew]] or in [[Hebrew script]]. It was sold by the Trustees in January 2017 to the [[National Library of Israel]].{{Cite news|url=https://worldisraelnews.com/national-library-gets-finest-collection-of-hebrew-prints-and-manuscripts/|title=National Library gets finest collection of Hebrew prints and manuscripts {{!}} World Israel News|date=2017-01-24|newspaper=World Israel News|access-date=2017-02-02|language=en-US}} It is named after [[Valmadonna]], a small town near [[Alessandria]] in north-west [[Italy]] with longstanding connections to the Lunzer family. The collection encompasses works from throughout the world, particularly [[Italy]], "the cradle of Hebrew printing", and covers over a millennium; many items in the collection are rare or unique, and many date back to the earliest Hebrew printings. According to [[Arthur Kiron]], curator of [[Judaica]] collections at the [[University of Pennsylvania]], "I don't know any other collection quite like it in private hands. It even rivals some of the great institutional collections in the world." ==Collection== Notable items in the collection include the following: *A well-preserved set of the [[Babylonian Talmud]] (1519–23) designed by a panel of scholars and codifying many aspects of how the Talmud is laid out, printed in [[Venice]] by [[Daniel Bomberg]]; Lunzer acquired this in 1980 from the collection of [[Westminster Abbey]] in exchange for a 900-year-old copy of the Abbey’s original Charter, and supporting endowments, fulfilling a 25-year dream."[http://blog.beliefnet.com/news/2009/02/rare-trove-of-hebrew-books-dis.php Rare Trove of Hebrew Books Displayed in NYC]", ''[[Beliefnet]] News'', February 10, 2009 This item was sold in 2015, see below. *A [[Hebrew Bible]] from [[England]] (known as the ''Codex Valmadonna I''), handwritten in 1189 and looted the next year during the destruction of the Jewish community of [[York]], which is the only known surviving Hebrew text from England dated prior to the expulsion of the [[Jews]] in 1290 under [[King Edward I]]., *A Franco-German [[Pentateuch]], probably written in the 10th or 11th century *A 12th-century scroll of the [[Pentateuch]] from the [[Samaritan]]s, written in the [[Samaritan alphabet]]. *The first [[Mikraot Gedolot]] *The earliest dated illustrated [[Haggadah of Pesach]] known to exist, printed in [[Prague]] in 1526. *A Pentateuch from [[Constantinople]] dated 1547, containing [[Spanish language|Spanish]] and [[Greek language|Greek]] translations written using Hebrew script."[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/02/12/books/12hebr.html?_r=1 A Lifetime’s Collection of Texts in Hebrew, at Sotheby’s]", [[Edward Rothstein]], ''[[New York Times]]'', February 11, 2009 *One of the first illustrated Hebrew books: A 1492 [[Mishna]] with commentary by [[Maimonides]] *The first book printed in Lisbon, 1489, [[Nahmanides]]’ commentary on the Pentateuch. *A 19th-century copy of ''[[One Thousand and One Nights|A Thousand and One Nights]]'' from [[Calcutta]], in [[Arabic]] spelled out in Hebrew script. *An illustrated guide for ''[[shechita]]'' from early 20th-century [[Pakistan]], with Hebrew and [[Marathi language|Marathi]] on facing pages. *A copy of every Hebrew book published in [[Cremona]] during the ten-year period such printing was allowed, ending in the 1560s. *The first book ever printed in [[Turkey]], a 1493 copy of the ''[[Arba'ah Turim]]''. *The first book ever printed in [[Africa]], a Hebrew book about prayer from [[Fes, Morocco|Fez]] dated 1516. *The first scientific work printed in [[Portugal]], by [[Abraham Zacuto]] in 1496. *An 1848 copy of the ''[[Communist Manifesto]]'' in [[German language|German]], one of eleven surviving copies of the first edition's February 1848 second printing in [[London]]."[https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9A0DE4DD133CF933A05756C0A960948260&scp=6&sq=valmadonna&st=cse 'Manifesto,' From 1848, Is Sold for $39,811]", ''[[New York Times]]'', May 30, 1986 *A Book of [[Psalms]] with part of its [[Radak]] commentary crossed out by a Christian censor. *A 1666 Dutch newspaper with a front page headline and article describing [[Sabbatai Zevi]]. *A Venice Sukka decoration from 1783. ==Collection sale== In early 2009, the collection, estimated to be worth in excess of US$40 million, was placed for sale by [[Sotheby's]], with the proviso that it be sold as a whole and not broken up, and remain accessible to scholars. The custodian [[Jack V. Lunzer]], who is not benefitting from the proceeds of the sale, has stated that "I would like our library to be acquired by the [[Library of Congress]]. That would be my great joy." After visiting the exhibition of the collection at Sotheby's, a scholar from the [[Drisha Institute]] wrote of Lunzer's achievement:
The morning of our visit, I studied the commentary of Rabbi [[David Kimhi]], who is known as the Radak, on Joseph's conflict with his brothers. Honestly, it felt like just another of the many rabbinic commentaries.... Then I went to the Valmadonna. Peering closely at one of the oldest manuscripts, I saw that it was a volume of Psalms with the Radak's commentary. In that instant, time and space collapsed as I found myself bound to every other Jew who has studied Kimhi's work since it was penned in the late 12th and early 13th centuries. That moment made clear to me that I am not simply a modern Jew studying in a contemporary yeshiva near [[Lincoln Center]]. I am tied to every other Jew through 800 years of history. I envision Kimhi hunched over his work, and wonder if his soul knows that even still we are learning from him, that his elucidation remains as relevant to the study of biblical text as it was to his contemporaries. The books of the Valmadonna – the books of our people – bring history alive [and] keep our history alive even when the communities that produce them are long dead.Cohen, Debra Nussbaum. [http://www.forward.com/articles/105933/ "Receiving the Original Text Messages"]. ''The Jewish Daily Forward''. May 13, 2009 (issue of May 22, 2009)
In May 2011, ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'' in London reported that the collection was still for sale, perhaps for around US$25 million.[http://www.thejc.com/news/world-news/48829/valmadonna-goes-back-market Valmadonna goes back on the market], by Robyn Rosen, 11 May 2011, ''[[The Jewish Chronicle]]'', accessed 21 March 2012. In December 2015, Sotheby's New York presided over the sale of the [[Daniel Bomberg]] ''Babylonian [[Talmud]]'' (1519-1523) from the Valmadonna Trust for $9.3 million, the copy that Lunzer obtained in trade from [[Westminster Abbey]] in 1980.[http://www.finebooksmagazine.com/press/2015/12/daniel-bombergs-16th-century-talmud-sells-for-93-million-at-sothebys-ny.phtml Fine Books Magazine], accessed 5 January 2016{{cite web|title=Tablet Magazine|url=http://www.tabletmag.com/scroll/196121/new-york-businessman-leon-black-buy-bomberg-babylonian-talmud-for-9-3-million|accessdate=23 December 2015}} In January 2017, the collection was sold to the [[National Library of Israel]] in January 2017 through a private sale arranged by Sotheby's. David Blumberg, Chairman of the Board of Directors of the [[National Library of Israel]], said:
“''The Valmadonna Trust Library represents an historic addition to our leading collection of Jewish manuscripts, prints and books, which reflect and embody the cultures of the Jewish people around the world and across the ages''”.
The Valmadonna Trust Library will be housed in the National Library of Israel's landmark new building in Jerusalem, due to open to the public in 2020.[https://worldisraelnews.com/national-library-gets-finest-collection-of-hebrew-prints-and-manuscripts/] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.sothebys.com/content/dam/sothebys/PDFs/ValmadonnaBrochure.pdf PDF sale brochure] from [[Sotheby's]] with descriptions and images *[https://www.nytimes.com/slideshow/2009/02/12/arts/design/20090212_HEBREW_SS_index.html Slideshow of the Valmadonna Trust Library displayed in Sotheby's in Manhattan] *[http://www.sothebys.com/video/movies/index_valmadonna.html Video about the collection] *[http://www.tabletmag.com/arts-and-culture/15302/treasure-trove/ "Treasure Trove"]. ''Tablet'' magazine, September 2009 article about the history of the collection *[http://thejewishstar.wordpress.com/2009/02/24/my-uncle-the-count-of-valmadonna/ February 2009 article in ''The Jewish Star'' describing aspects of the collection] *[http://seforim.blogspot.co.uk/2009/08/twenty-five-years-at-valmadonna-trust.html ''Twenty-Five Years at the Valmadonna Trust Library''], by Pauline Malkiel [[Category:English book and manuscript collectors]] [[Category:Hebrew manuscripts]] [[Category:Jewish printing and publishing]] [[Category:Jewish illuminated manuscripts]]

page.title: Wall of the Sun and Wall of the Moon

revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = The Wall of the Sun<ref name=UnescoSOL>{{Cite web|url=http://www.unesco.org/visit/uk/notices/miro1.htm|accessdate=28 December 2013|title=UNESCO Catalogue}}</ref> | image = Wall_of_the_Sun.jpg | artist = [[Joan Miró i Ferrà]] and [[Josep Llorens i Artigas]] | year = 1955–1958 | height_metric = 2.20 | width_metric = 15 | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Paris]] | museum = [[UNESCO]] building | coordinates = {{coord|48|50|58|N|2|18|22|E|scale:1000_region:FR|display=inline}} }} {{Infobox artwork | title = The Wall of the Moon | artist = [[Joan Miró i Ferrà]] and [[Josep Llorens i Artigas]] | year = 1955–1958 | height_metric = 2.20 | width_metric = 7.50 | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = ft | city = [[Paris]] | museum = [[UNESCO]] building | coordinates = {{coord|48|50|58|N|2|18|22|E|scale:1000_region:FR|display=inline}} }} The '''''Wall of the Sun''''' and '''''Wall of the Moon''''' are a pair of [[mural]]s made of ceramics and designed by the [[Catalan people|Catalan]] artist [[Joan Miró]] for the [[UNESCO]] building in Paris. The works were carried out by the ceramicist [[Josep Llorens Artigas]] in 1955.<ref name=Dupin>{{cite book|last=Dupin|first=Jacques|title=Miró|date=2004|publisher=Éditions Flammarion|location=Paris|isbn=2-0803-0450-X|page=395}}</ref> Initially, the walls were installed on the Place de Fontenoy in Paris, but afterwards were enclosed in a building that was constructed in order to protect them from damage caused by acid rain.<ref name=Unesco>{{cite web|title=The Wall of the Sun|url=http://www.unesco.org/visit/uk/notices/miro1.htm|publisher=UNESCO website|accessdate=10 May 2014}}</ref>
== History == [[Joan Miró]] and [[Josep Llorens Artigas]] met in 1910 at the school of art of the artist [[Francesc Galí]] (1880–1965), in Barcelona. Since the 1940s, Miró and Josep Llorens Artigas started an artistic duo that spawned objects and large ceramic murals such as one at the [[Unesco]] building in Paris or the ceramic wall of the [[Barcelona–El Prat Airport|Barcelona Airport]]. These works fused Miró lexicon with the essential qualities of the arts of earth and fire.<ref name=artigas>{{Cite web | title= Joan Gardy Artigas, Spanish (1938 - )|url=http://rogallery.com/Artigas_Joan_Gardy/artigas-biography.html| editor = rogallery.com| accessdate= 28 September 2011}}</ref>
In 1955 Joan Miró was contacted by the heads of UNESCO to ask if he want to take part of the team of artists that decorated the future headquarters of the institution that is located in Paris.<ref name=runner93>{{Cite journal|last=Corredor-Matheos|first=Josep|title=The Miró-Artigas Murals|journal=Catalonia Culture|date=October 1993|pages=34–37|volume=35}}</ref> Once agreed, they granted the exterior walls of the building conferences, two perpendicular walls of three meters high and seven meters long and fifteen, respectively. Miró proposed to make a ceramic mural in collaboration with Llorens Artigas.
In 1956, Miró began working on the mural in his studio in [[Palma, Majorca|Palma]]. The following year he went to the [[Cave of Altamira|Caves of Altamira]] in with Llorens Artigas inspired to carry on the work,<ref name="Mink2000">{{Cite book|first=Janis |last=Mink|title=Joan Miró, 1893-1983|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=uDW3HgIw7aYC&pg=PA93|year=2000|editor=Taschen|isbn=978-3-8228-5975-9|pages=93–}}</ref><ref name="Preckler2003">{{Cite book|first=Ana María |last=Preckler|title=Historia del arte universal de los siglos XIX y XX|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MJ_edWCq2UoC&pg=PA236|date= 1 January 2003|editor=Editorial Complutense|isbn=978-84-7491-707-9|pages=236–}}</ref> by seeing "the first mural in the world".<ref name=BYN59>{{Cite journal|last=Miró|first=Joan|title=Como hice los murales para la UNESCO|journal=Blanco y Negro|date=6 July 1959|volume=2457|language=Spanish}}</ref> They also visit the [[Colegiata y Claustro de Santa Juliana]] and the romanesque collection of the Museum of Art of Catalonia, the current [[Museu Nacional d'Art de Catalunya|MNAC]].<ref name=runner93 />
=== Construction === Once inspired, Miró moved to [[Gallifa]], at the workshop of Artigas, to proceed to prepare the tile mural. It took 35 batches, 25 tons of wood, 4 tons of sandstone and 200 kilos of enamel.<ref name=runner93 /> Once finished, the pieces were transported to Paris. Although he had worked in large formats, he had never done ceramics. Beside the ceramist Josep Llorens Artigas, they failed to find technical feasibility for baking pottery in a way that allows to obtain a background textures similar to the paintings of that time.<ref>Rebull, Melania (1994) p. 65</ref> It was decided that the composition was on the subjects of "Sun" and "Moon".<ref>Malet, Rosa M. (1992) pg. 107-112</ref>
=== Inauguration === The two mosaic murals were assembled ''in situ'' by a team of technicians under the direct supervision of Miró and Llorens Artigas.<ref name=caca/> The works were inaugurated in 1958, as same as the building, and received rave reviews. Even one of the murals, the ''Wall of the Sun'' won the Biennial Prize of Guggenheim Foundation.<ref name=runner93 /><ref name=caca/> Miró later return to work for UNESCO, designing the UNESCO Medal for [[Pablo Picasso]].
=== Conservation === Initially, the walls were outdoors, but later moved inside the building to protect them from damage caused by [[acid rain]].<ref name=caca />
== Awards and recognition == * 1958 - The biennial international award of the [[Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation|Guggenheim Foundation]] for the ''Wall of the Sun''.<ref name=caca>{{Cite web|url=http://portal.unesco.org/es/ev.php-URL_ID=26465&URL_DO=DO_TOPIC&URL_SECTION=201.html|accessdate=11 May 2014|title=Joan Miró en la UNESCO|editor=UNESCO|language=spanish}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artists/bios/11111?tmpl=component&print=1|language=catalan|accessdate=28 December 2013|title=Miró al Guggenheim|editor=Guggenheim Foundation}}</ref><ref name=Guggenheim>{{cite web|title=Joan Miró and Josep Llorens Artigas|url=http://www.guggenheim.org/new-york/collections/collection-online/artists/bios/11111?tmpl=component&print=1|publisher=Guggenheim Museum|accessdate=10 May 2014}}</ref>
== References == {{reflist|2}}
== Bibliography == * {{Cite book|last=Dupin|first=Jacques|title=Miró|pages=390–391|location=Barcelona|editor=Polígrafa|year=1993|isbn=84-343-0726-X}} * {{Cite book|first=Carme |last=Escudero |first2=Teresa |last2=Montaner|title=Joan Miró, desfilada d'obsessions: 14 juny-2 setembre 2001|location=Barcelona|editor=Fundació Joan Miró|year=2001|isbn=84-923925-9-2}} *{{Cite book|last=Punyet Miró |first=Joan |last2=Gardy Artigas |first2=Joan |last3= Calero |first3=Cristina |title=Joan Miró, Josep Llorens Artigas: ceramics: catalogue raisonné, 1941-1981|pages=338–399|location=Paris|editor=D. Lelong|year=2007|isbn=978-2-86882-079-2}} * {{Cite book|last=Penrose|first=Roland|title=Miró|location=London|editor=Thames and Hudson |year=1993 |isbn=84-233-1976-8 |ref=harv}}
{{Joan Miró}}
[[Category:Murals]] [[Category:Joan Miró]] [[Category:1958 paintings]] [[Category:UNESCO]] [[Category:Arts in France]] [[Category:Moon in art]]

[[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Alfoers graf Minahasa Sulawesi TMnr 10016738.jpg|thumb|Waruga with carvings]] [[File:COLLECTIE TROPENMUSEUM Oude Menadonese graven bij Sawangan tussen Aermadidi en Tondano TMnr 60033445.jpg|thumb|Sawangan waruga]]
'''Waruga''' are a type of [[sarcophagus]] or above ground [[tomb]] traditionally used by the [[Minahasa]]ns of [[North Sulawesi]], [[Indonesia]]. They are made of stone and consist or a ridged upper part and a box shaped lower section.
Dead Minahasans were originally wrapped in woka, a type of leaf. Woka is the leaf of the fan palm, Livistona. Then they were put in wooden coffins.{{citation needed|date=August 2015}} In the 9th century the Minahasa started using waruga.
Bodies are put in a position facing north. They seated with heel and toe attaches to the buttocks and the head "kissing" the knees. The Minhasa believe their ancestors came from the north.
In 1828 the Dutch banned the use of waruga<ref name=indo>[https://books.google.com/books?id=WKoIooGXjPYC&pg=PA962&lpg=PA962&dq=Waruga+sarcophagus&source=bl&ots=uvEGJrG_rg&sig=WFinmy8qUpeos4oRln9NyeUQte0&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CEsQ6AEwCmoVChMIuffQyI2fxwIVzCUeCh2rQA2z#v=onepage&q=Waruga%20sarcophagus&f=false Indonesia] by Stephen Backshall page 962</ref> and the Minahasa started making coffins. Disease outbreak, including typhoid and cholera, was feared. And Christian practice is to bury the dead.
Waruga in Tonsea have carvings and reliefs showing how the bodies are stored in their respective waruga and illustrating livelihoods.
There are about 370 Warugas (waruga-waruga) in [[Rap-Rap]] (15), [[Airmadidi Down]] (211) and [[Sawangan, North Sulawesi]] (144). They are a tourist attraction and were listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1995 in the [[waruga archaeological park]] in Sawangan. At Taman Purbakala Waruga-Waruga, the sarcophagi have been collected from surrounding areas and at a nearby museum porcelain, armbands, axes and bone fragments are exhibited.<ref name=indo/> Most of the waruga have been looted for valuable contents.
==See also== *[[Podom]] *[[Veneration of the dead]] (ancestor worship)
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
'''''Welsh Music History / Hanes Cerddoriaeth Cymru''''' is published by the [[University of Wales Press]] on behalf of the [[Centre for Advanced Welsh Music Studies]], [[Bangor University]]. It is a biennial bilingual journal contain academic articles and reviews relating to [[Welsh music]] and music in Wales.
It is being digitised by the [[National Library of Wales#Welsh Journals Online|Welsh Journals Online]] project at the [[National Library of Wales]].
==External links== *[http://welshjournals.llgc.org.uk/browse/listarticles/llgc-id:1175725/llgc-id:1175726 Volume 1, 1996] *[http://welshjournals.llgc.org.uk/browse/listarticles/llgc-id:1175725/llgc-id:1175979 Volume 2, 1997] *[http://welshjournals.llgc.org.uk/browse/listarticles/llgc-id:1175725/llgc-id:1176280 Volume 3, 1999] *[http://welshjournals.llgc.org.uk/browse/listarticles/llgc-id:1175725/llgc-id:1176637 Volume 4, 2000] *[http://welshjournals.llgc.org.uk/browse/listarticles/llgc-id:1175725/llgc-id:1176866 Volume 5, 2002] *[http://welshjournals.llgc.org.uk/browse/listarticles/llgc-id:1175725/llgc-id:1177095 Volume 6, 2004]
